prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Statutory criteria for transfer—Just and efficient conduct of litigation

para.paratext: This statutory requirement is directed most clearly to the discretion of the Panel. The statute offers no guidance on the meaning of this requirement and the Panel has never articulated a single standard to be used in determining if this requirement is met in litigation before it. The Panel has stated a number of factors in various cases before it that indicate that the just and efficient conduct of the litigation would be advanced by transfer under 28 U.S.C.A. section 1407. These factors are to some degree present in most of the cases before the Panel and are not directly identified as a factor justifying transfer as set forth in § 5:17, below. These factors are more general in nature, and are more accurately recognized as indicators to the Panel that the threshold requirements for transfer are met. The Panel then considers the more specific factors identified in § 5:17 to determine if transfer is prudent under the facts of the cases. These general factors relating to the threshold question of whether the just and efficient conduct of the litigation will be advanced by transfer include:[1]
—Avoidance of conflicting rulings in various cases;[2]
—Prevention of duplication of discovery on common issues;[3]
—Avoidance of conflicting and duplicative pretrial conferences;[5]
—Reduce burden on parties by allowing division of workload among several attorneys.[7]

The Panel has rejected the argument that transfer is not appropriate because it tends to encourage the filing on non-meritorious or frivolous claims.[8] In doing so, the Panel pointed out that the transferee judge “committed to disposing of spurious claims quickly.”[9]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See generally Wilson Herndon, Section 1407 and Antitrust Multidistrict Litigation—The First Decade, 47 A.B.A. Antitrust L.J. 1161, 1171 (1969).
